Re: BOAC aeroplane accident. iFrom The Residency Surgeon, Bahrain, To The Secretary to the Hon’ble the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bahrain. Sir, I have the honour to forward the following report in connection with the British Overseas Airways Corporation air plane accident of the 23rd August, I received information of the accident from the British Overseas Airways Corporation at about 5-20 a.m. and proceeded to the jetty immediately. On arrival sixteen injured persons and one dead had just been landed. They were sent on to the Government Hospital in transport supplied by British Overseas Airways Corporation, ^-he Station Superintendent informed me that there were still nine passengers in the submerged plane; but there was no hope of any of them being alive. 3. Of the sixteen injured five were detained in the hospital, Mr. Fitzgerald, a passenger was in a state of nervous shock and had fractured ribs, the Pilot and Steward had bad scalp wounds and two Chinese passengers with severe sprains and contusions, all the remainder sustained only minor injuries and were sent back to the British Overseas Airways Corporation Rest House after being dressed. 4. The Station Superintendent asked us to make preparations to rescue nine dead bodies which he thought would be rescued from the submerged plane during the course of the day. Under instructions from the Political Agent, I together with the inspector and a sergeant of the police went to the jetty at 2 p.m. for identification and Medical examination of the Dead still to be recovered from the plane, by 6 p.m, only four bodies were recovered making a total of five bodies for the day. The remaining five bodies wererecovered at odd times during the next five days. All were accounted for the the 28th ultimo. r 5. The Government Hospital Mortuary can accommodate only three bodies, which is ample for its legitimate purpose. Five bodies however in an advanced state of putrification had to be kept on in the Mortuary all night and prepared for burial. This caused great inconvenience to the Hospital Staff and in patients, as can well be imagined. It was indeed fortunate that the remaining fatilities were not recovered the same day. I am of the opinion that a police morgue if opened and equipped to deal with fatalities .from accidents etc. is a real necessity. The matron of the Hospital with help from the nursing staff had to prepare putrifying corpses kept in the Hospital Mortuary for burial, which is not part of their duties for obvious reasons. After the experience of the nigh^of the 23rd with five corpses in the Mortuary, the remainder were examined at the jetty and sent direct to the cemetery. I have the honour to be, Sir, Your most obedient servant, Sgd. W. Steele. Residency SurgeonD.O. No. C/1021. The 15th of October, 1947. While X appreciate the force and truth of the Residency Surgeon’s remarks about the inadequacy of the Bahrain Governraent’s facilities for dealing with accidents indeed, there is no event which brings one into personal contact with the working of the Bahrain Government’s Departments that does not bring home to one their in adequacy -, I feel it is for us to advise the Bahrain Government that their facilities are inadequate, and to leave it to them to decide how best to remedy the defi ciencies. 3. The Bahrain Government received £1604.16.2 this year from the British overseas Airways Corporation for the rent of the aerodrome for 1947 and for aircraft ser vices, additional to the first, that used it during 1946 - vide correspondence forwarded with Residency endorsement No. 1035-S, dated the 30th May, 1947. In addition, Bahrain benefited from the trade brought to the Island by the British Overseas Airways Corporation, and from customs duties paid on the Corporation’s local purchases. 4. All the services pertaining specifically to their aircraft are provided by the British Overseas Airways Corporation; so I feel that the British Overseas Airways Corporation, which does not have sufficient hospital cases to justify its having its own hospital, has a right to expect, in return for its contribution to the Bahrain Government’s revenues and to general prosperity here, reasonable standards of general administration in Bahrain. In this general administration, I incluae adequate facili ties for attending to casualties from accidents. 5. On this occasion it was not only the mortuary that proved inadequate: the Bahrain Government’s Chief Medical Officer was on leave and no full time relief had been pro vided in his place; the air-conditioning apparatus in the European ward broke down; and, when it was working, it was, I understand, so noisy that it seriously disturbed the only patient on the D.I. list. Indeed, it appears to be generally agreed among the doctors who attended him that it *as only his removal to the Bahrain petroleum Company’s hospital in Awali, where he still is, that saved his life. /6. It so, The Ron’ble Lt-Col. air Rupert Hay, K.C.I.E., C.b.I., political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bahrain.6. A serious explosion in the refinery could easily tax the Company’s - medical resources beyond capacity, while a fire or an explosion in a ship, a petrol filling station, or the water distillation plant in Manama could more than fill the existing hospital accommodation here; and X feel that adequate provision for such emergencies is overdue. 7. I consider also that the Adviser should be warned now that it will not again be possible to lend the ser vices of the Agency durgeon to deputize for the Bahrain Government’s Chief Medical Officer, because the Agency Surgeon already has more than enough work of his own. yours sincerely,D*0 •Ko • 1809-S The Residency, Bahrain, the 20 th October 1947. titleInfo.title: 'File 32/22 Bahrain Government's Facilities for Dealing with Accidents'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the back cover with 10; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is also present in parallel between ff 2-6; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence.

mods.abstract: This file contains correspondence between British officials regarding concerns that the Government of Bahrain did not possess the appropriate medical and emergency facilities to deal with large-scale accidents in the country.These concerns were raised by W B Steele, the Residency Surgeon in Bahrain, in September 1947 after the crash of a British Overseas Airways Corporation (BOAC) plane in August 1947. Following the crash, in which a number of passengers were killed, the Bahraini authorities struggled to cope with the number of dead bodies.
